author: @anna-878
text: You definitely encouraged me to showcase my examples of work. I work in public sector and I think projects I am involved in are very interesting (eg finding all homes in my county without electricity or helping the refugees team to support Ukrainian refugees through a map where they could see all refugees locations plus nearby schools and GP practices, also recently I was matching - using Python and Companies House apis - the list of companies active in our county with their SIC codes to understand what industry type they represent).  I think they are very interesting cases how data science  is helping  local authority make strategic decisions, but I don't know yet how much I can talk about my day -to day job? Maybe you have some ideas? In theory public sector ways of working should be accessible to the public,and the only law which might stop me is I think GDPR.... (but that can be just protected during my content creation...) I know that private company has other laws to stop me from showcasing stuff....  Of course I want to do this content in my free time outside of work :)

author: @arthurmiller5276
text: üëè This is an awesome video on the different "Data Science" roles. (Though I've never played Mario and got lost when it focusing on one role, showing only one title at a time, and comparing to the others. ME: "WAIT! Was Luigi the 'engineer' or the 'analyst'?")      I will say that, towards the end, it gets a bit discouraging. And perhaps it begins with the interviewees. Lots of vloggers and guests appear to be fresh out of college with multiple degrees, including masters, or took one sponsored advertiser's certificate course and landed six-figure FAANG jobs in a matter of weeks with little or, in the case of one, no effort to even submit a resume.      This doesn't seem realistic and gives the impression, much like many job postings, that anyone without a masters and decades of experience in technical skills like Python or PBI AND Tableau, etc is not "qualified" for even a basic "Data Science" role.      This isn't meant as a criticism, but merely "constructive feedback" to hopefully encourage followers to pursue a career in data science.

author: @itsjustme684

We suck at that , most of us  But if i dont find opportunities here, i do believe my abilities to master more than 5 languages will land me places.   I love everyone's opinions.

author: @jaredalbin5658
text: I'm a Senior Data Engineer.  However, I have performed the same work under these different titles as well: "Data Integration Specialist II" "Technical ERP Developer" "Data Analyst IV"  Job functions: SQL, ETL, SQL Reports, Dashboards, Data Warehousing, automations with Informatica, SSIS, ADF, Python, C#.  I think a Data Analyst can grow to become either a Data Engineer or a Data Scientist, and any of these can become a Data Manager, just give yourself some time for gray hairs to grow. Although this is the first time I have ever heard of a Machine Learning Engineer.
